column7: NAFAWU: Namibia Fuel and Allied Workers Union
column17: 70 fuel attendants from various service stations across the country gathered at the Khomasdal soccer stadium on Monday in protest over their wages and working conditions.
A small group of people including representatives of civil society organisations and opposition parties held a peaceful demonstration against the proposed changes to the Namibian Constitution.
A young woman, Frieda Ndatipo, is killed during a violent confrontation between a group of struggle kids and the police near the Swapo headquarters in Katutura.
Struggle Kids go to the place where Frieda Ndatipo was shot dead Wednesday. The protesters block Swapo Secretary General Nangolo Mbumbas official vehicle from entering the party premises.
20 Struggle Kids attempt to storm a police station in order to free one of their comrades.
Residents stage a demonstration over the recent rape and murder of a pregnant woman at the village.

A group of Dundee Precious Metals Tsumeb (DPMT) and other community workers staged a strike agained the Canadian owned mining company regarding wages and working conditions. The protests included members of the Mineworkers Union of Nambia (MUN).

Some residents on the pathway of the new Oshandi-Oshiweda road are refusing to vacate in exchange for compensation due to family conflicts. Others refuse to move claiming the compensation is too little.

About 50 workers at Windhoeker Maschinenfabrik picketed and presented the company with a petition and list of grievances. They gave management two weeks to address the issues which include a change of some personnel.
150 residents of Walvis Bay peacefully marched to the municipality offices to deliver a petition demanding new plots for the homeless and backyard squatters.

A swapo meeting was aborted by a local chief who accuses the meeting leaders of trying to dethrone him. Although large crowds had already gathered, the meeting was rescheduled for an undisclosed date.

An angry mob stormed a clinic to vent their frustration with a nurse who has allegedly injured several patients, including scalding a security guard with boiling water. The mob were denied entry and the nurse was guarded and removed.

E-Med Resuce Service 24 called the police to remove the deputy secretary general of NAFINU who they accused of trespassing and interfering with meeting proceedings. The NAFINU representative was there to protest E-Meds treatment of shop stewards and he was not evicted by the police.
The ""struggle kids"" held demonstrations saying the government should respond to their requests and deliver promised jobs before the elections on 28 nov.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: SWAPO Youth League members Job Amupanda, Dimbulukweni Nauyoma and George Kambala protested land rights by sitting in on empty land in suburb of Klein Kuppe in Windhoek. All three were suspended by SWAPO.
Over 100 young people protested in front of the Windhoek mayors office (coordinates unavailable) where they demanded residential land as their birth right.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: Youth protested in front of the Windhoek Municipality office on Nov. 24, presenting 14,000 applications for residential land as part of the Affirmative Repositioning campaign.
Young professionals staged a mass demonstration for land reform and submitted over 14,000 applications for residential land.

Members of a community liaison committee and unemployed from Keetmanshoop protested in front of the offices of Salini Impregilo construction company, demanding the suspension of recruitment for the Neckartal Dam project.

Hendrik Tseib Community Liaison Committee members and supporters demonstrated in front of the offices of the construction company Salini Impregilo demanding that the company suspend recruitment for the Neckartal dam project
30 workers at the Roads Contractor Company protest over pay package and demand removal of acting chief executive officer.
Workers at the Roads Contractor Company held a peaceful demonstration to express discontent over the CEOs pay package.
Members of a community liaison community blocked the entrance to Neckertal Dam to prevent 600 Salini employees and subcontractors from reporting to work.

column6: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: Police use rubber batons to assault six inmates following an attempted escape from Keetmanshoop holidng cells.

column7: NAPWU: Namibia Public Worker's Union; Labour Group (Namibia)
column17: 100 school secretaries and cleaners protested for salary hikes and incentives by gathering at Oluno sports field in Ondangwa.
Over 60 students at the Polytechnic of Namibia protested against the 16% increase in registration fees.

Residents of Tsumeb marched to protest against gender-based violence and other violent crimes. Protesters presented a petition to the Tsumeb Municipality that calls for sheebeen and bar owners to honor their liquor licences and not sell alcohol to minors.
200 workers of Swakop Uraniums Husab Mine in Erongo staged a demonstration at the companies headquarters in Swakopmund, demanding better pay, housing allowances, and medical aid cover.
18 youth volunteers at Berg Aukas training center 20km east of Grootfontein staged a protest to demand permanent jobs or increase in monthly allowance.
Residents of Ongenga Constitutency protested, accusing the True Gospel Salvation Ministries of noise pollution and child abuse.
60 residents of Okahandja demonstrated at the municipality offices demanding the removal of the entire council and open committee meetings.

Landless occupied council land in Swakomund, Godhardt Kandume and Engelhardt/Uirab in demand of land rights. The protesters erected two shacks before police dispersed the crowd and arrested protest leaders.

Starting on Feb 16, 60 elderly people camped on the lawn in front of the Okahandja Municipalty building, calling for the removal of municipality council and staff members. Protesters were removed by police on Feb. 20.
60 workers at the Langer Heinrich Uranium mine protested Feb 16 and 17 calling for the removal of the managing director and payment of annual bonuses.

Starting on Feb 16, 60 elderly people camped on the lawn in front of the Okahandja Municipalty building, calling for the removal of municipality council and staff members. Protesters were removed by police on Feb. 20.

Starting on Feb 16, 60 elderly people camped on the lawn in front of the Okahandja Municipalty building, calling for the removal of municipality council and staff members. Protesters were removed by police on Feb. 20.

Starting on Feb 16, 60 elderly people camped on the lawn in front of the Okahandja Municipalty building, calling for the removal of municipality council and staff members. Protesters were removed by police on Feb. 20.
90 women with the Tsumeb police held a march against gender-based violence and organized crime over the weekend.
Rioters looted Club Pamodzi in Katutura and attacked a security guard who then shot one of the rioters dead.
Nurses at Onandjokwe Lutheran Hospital in Oniipa protested over delayed salaries.

Villagers in Otjomunguindi, Otumumbonde and Ondjora in Otjinene Constituency have blocked construction workers from collecting water from community boreholes, in protest of the governments plans to build a resettlement area for the San people.
100 students at the Institute of Bankers Namibia protested outside the institutions head office demanding the removal of acting CEO.

Union of Institutional and Household Employees of Namibia demonstrated to the Ministry of Labour, Industrial Relations and Employment Creation, in protest of a newly introduced minimum wage for domestic workers.
5 men stoned a man to death with bricks and beer bottles after the man allegedly stole a cell phone.
40 workers at Roads Contractor Co. in Windhoek protested against delayed payments.
100 villagers of Ovitoto in Otjozondjupa Region (captital Otjiwarongo coordinates used) protested, demanding the government to incorporate a farm into the communal area.
2 died and 2 sustained injuries after picking up an unexploded ordnance in Omawe village.
Protests against xenophobic attacks against Africans in South Africa. Protesters marched from Indepence Museum to the SA High Commission in Klein, Windhoek.
100 protesters in Kalimbeza demonstrated against substandard government-funded roadwork.
Rioters destroy and burn fences and assault villagers on land that rioters say belongs to Ondonga traditional leadership.
Namib Mills workers protested against company mismanagement.
Supporters of Chief Kilus Munjuku III protested when supporters of the late Chief Munjuku II paid homage at his burial site. Police intervened to move the protesters aside.
300 NovaNam workers in Luderitz protested against the recruitment of foreigners.
Outapi construction workers hold a peaceful demonstration concerning lack of safety in the work place.

column9: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: Hundreds of rioters demanded to be allocated plots for businesses, blocking the entrance to the offices of Katima town council, until the mayor and chief executive officer of Katima would give them answers. Police and special forces used teargas to disperse the crowds.
Teachers in Ondangwa protest, calling for stricter punishments for crimes and murders.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: Swapo Youth League demonstrate in Oniipa, calling for the harsher sentences for perpetrators of gender-based violence.
50 TransNamib workers demonstrated in Otjiwarongo and submitted a petition for the Namibia National Labour Organisation to be their recognised trade union representative.
200 residents of Camp Five in Outjo protested to demand electricity in their shacks.
Onandjokwe Lutheran Hospital staff staged a sit-in protesting delayed June salaries.

column9: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: 300 rioters used shovels, rakes and axes to grab land plots in Goreangab. Police and Special Field Forces were deployed.
Rio Tinto Uranium mine workers went on strike and marched to the management office in protest of the companies use of cameras in haul trucks.
Shoprite workers strike over unfair labour practices and wage increases. The strikers hold peaceful demonstrations at various locations.
Shoprite workers strike over unfair labour practices and wage increases. The strikers hold peaceful demonstrations at various locations.
Shoprite workers strike over unfair labour practices and wage increases. The strikers hold peaceful demonstrations at various locations.
Shoprite workers strike over unfair labour practices and wage increases. The strikers hold peaceful demonstrations at various locations.
2 cattle herders injured and in critical condition when a mortar bomb exploded in Okantjongoro Ovitoto Reserve, 10km from Okahandja. Another unexploded bomb found at the scene.
Farmers demonstrate against the theft of cattle by suspected Angolans.
Protests against the release of a rape, murder suspect.
Youth and teachers marched against gender-based violence.
Protests at Swapo headquarters in Windhoek to demand promised jobs by government.
Government employees demonstrate at Oshakati, demanding improved working conditions.
Namibia Poultry Industry workers protested, calling for an end to of transportation of staff in open trucks.
Manica and Namibia Stevedoring workers in Walvis Bay hold demonstrations demanding better salaries and benefits.
Protests over lack of water in Choiganab.
Kavango Development Progress Forum protests against corruption by town council.
Struggle kids protests at SWAPO offices in Oshana demanding employment.
NAPWU workers protest for higher salaries in Oshakati.
NAPWU workers protest for higher salaries in Swakopmund.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: SWAPO members protest against the nomination of a councillor.
Struggle kids in Windhoek protest demanding jobs.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: Swapo members protest against the list of party candidates for local elections.
Air Namibia and TransNamib employees hold demonstrations over mismanagement.
Government cleaners and gardeners protest for higher salaries.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation
column17: Narraville residents joined by SWAPO members demonstrate to appeal for stronger laws against drug dealers.
900 fishermen in Walvis Bay stop work demanding better salaries and medical care.
Okahandja residents protest against local councillor running for a second term.
Struggle kids marched in Katutura demanding government jobs.
50 pensioners from Katutura protested demanding write-offs of debt for housing bonds.
Family members of a murder victim gather at Keetmanshoops courthouse in protest of bail.

400 struggle kids rioted, threw bottles and and chairs, demanding jobs with government agencies. One rioter tried to strangle a Nambian Exile Kids Association staff member with a scarf, leaving injuries to her shoulder.
Struggle kids riot at SWAPO offices in Oshakati, destroying water meters.

column7: SWAPO: South West Africa Peoples Organisation; UDF: United Democratic Front
column17: SWAPO supporters gather in front of UDF offices in Khorizas and UDF supporters gathered outside to meet them and chant slogans against each other. Police fired tear gas at UDF supporters.
Struggle kids riot and clash with police at a SWAPO rally in Ongwediva. One policeman injured.
Struggle kids riot and clash with police on Okandjengedi main road in Oshakati.
Struggle kids block gates to SWAPO offices in Oshakati.
300 struggle kids attempted to disrupt a SWAPO rally. Police fired tear gas, resulting in clashes with the rioters.
Protests against bail being granted for alleged human traffickers.
Defusal: Police discover and detonate an anti-tank mine at Onekaku village near Oshigambo.
TransNamib employees protest for equal treatment.

column8: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: Mob of struggle kids gather in Windhoek at Brakwater settlement, where 400 struggle kids were relocated to the Ndilimani Cultural Troupe Farm on Dec 12. Rioters blocked roads and attacked residents with pangas. Special Reserve Forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets.
Mob of struggle kids gather in Windhoek at Brakwater settlement, attacked residents with panga knives.
Clashes between struggle kids rioters and an armed white farmer. Rioters threw rocks at farm and then chopped farmer with a machete. Farmer fired back with bullets. 4 rioters injured.

column8: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: Struggle kids block roads near Brakwater settlement. Special Reserve Forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets.
Child injured playing with a hand grenade in Kehemu near Rundu.
Students protest against increased registration fees.
Students protest registration fees.
Defusal: Explosive device found in Eros.
Students in Ongwediva demonstrated against registration fees.
Newspaper vendors riot in Windhoek, against low commissions.
Residents in Kavango held a demonstration against underfunding.
Struggle kids damaged a bus and attacked bus driver with rods and stones, along Brakwater road. The driver sustained serious injuries and broken limbs. 7 were later arrested.
Struggle kids smash windows at a construction site in Brakwater.
400 students protest over quality of food at university hostels.

column9: Police Forces of Namibia (1990-) Special Reserve Force
column17: Rioters illegally grab land in Tutaleni township on outskirts of Walvis Bay, throwing stones, bricks and sticks at police and assaulting a police officer. Also damaged police vehicles and windows in front of police station. 4 injured including 1 policeman. Rubber bullets used to disperse rioters. Special Reserve Forces deployed. 5 arrested at the scene of riots.

Residents of Kuviku settlement on outskirts of Rehoboth riot over land allocations, damaging a police vehicle. Police fired bullets, injuring several rioters. 6 arrested at the scene. No reports of serious injuries. Gunshots also heard during the riots.

In lead up to a planned protest, a group of struggle kids born in exile tore down tents and got into an altercation with another group that also considers themselves struggle kids because their parents were born in exile. Occurred near SWAPO offices in Okandjengedi near Oshakati.
100 struggle kids began a march from Oshakati to Windhoek, protesting for economic freedom.
Residents of Oshiyashemanya in Oshikoto Region (capital Omuthiya used) demonstrated against a suspected rapist and murder receiving bail.
200 taxi drivers demonstrated in Goreangab against high traffic fines.
1000 AR protesters against construction of a new parliament building in Katutura.
Struggle kids block traffic in Katutura during march from Brackwater to Katutura.
Salini workers at Neckartal Dam near Keetmanshoop go on strike and lock gates to premises.
Citizens of Rehoboth staged a peaceful demonstration demanding land that was promised under the Harambe Prosperity Plan
Children of the Struggle set the Brakwater Farm where they have been camped alight and then attacked the firefighters who came to douse the flames.
Children of the Struggle set up a barricade on the main Okahandja Road near the Brakwater Farm where they are based. Police dispersed them using rubber bullets and teargas.
Former SWATF and Koevoet members marched to the British High Commission to petition the international community to pressure the Namibian government to recognise their status as War Veterans

Members of ""Children of the Struggle"" marched from Brakwater to the SWAPO headquarters in Windhoek, where they blocked the entrance. Police attempted to disperse them, so they threw stones, whereupon the police fired rubber bullets.

About 100 Rehoboth residents took to the streets to protest alleged poor service delivery and corruption by the Rehoboth Town Council (RTC). The protest was organised by the DTA (Democratic Turnhalle Alliance).

column7: NASAWU: Namibian Seaman and Allied Workers Union
column17: Gendor workers with the trade union NASAWU in Walvis Bay staged a peaceful protest.
Teachers in Khomas Region staged a peaceful demonstration wth the Namibia National Teachers Union. They marched to the labour commissioners office in Khomasdal to hand over a petition.
Hifikepunye Pohamba Campus in Ongwediva held a peaceful demonstration by students demanding for one of the lecturers to be removed permanently from the campus within five working days.
Lessons were disrupted at the University of Namibia campus at Oshakati as students demonstrated, demanding that the university builds them a hostel at the satellite campus.
Close to 1840 teachers as part of the Namibian National Teachers Union at Rundu in the Kavango East region took to the streets vowing that the strike will go on for days until their demands are met.
Students staged a demonstration in Omungwelume, saying learners desperate for accommodation and food turn to private individuals, some of whom expect sexual favours in return.

A handful of peoples marched to Walvis Bays Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources Office to bring to the attention their outcry and objection to the capture of Namibian marine species for export to Asia.

column7: NATAU: Namibia Transport and Allied Workers Union; NASGWU: Namibia Security Guard and Watchmens Union; NISU: Namibia Independent Security Union
column17: Security guards in Windhoek demonstrated, demanding a 7% salary increase. The workers are represented by Namibia Transport and Allied Workers Union (Natau), Namibia Security Guards and Watchmens Union and the Namibia Independent Security Union (Nisu).
Keetmanshoop residents took to the streets to protest against the intended extension of an electricity management contract between the local council and Southern Electricity Company (Selco).
The Aroab community took to the streets to protest over what they called ""discriminatory remarks"" by the Karas (capital - Keetsmanshoop) governor.
Residents of Omaruru staged a demonstration to pressurise the municipality into responding to a petition they handed over last month regardsing the sale of property.

Clashes with the police took place and involved about 80 struggle kids, who have been picketing outside the Danger Ashipala Police Training Centre in Ondangwa. They used huge tree branches and metal objects to block the entrance while they sat on the objects they used to block the road.
Land activists, under the organization of the Affirmative Repositioning (AR), protested in front of the office of Oshana regional governor in Oshakati.

Swakopmund residents handed over a petition during a march to Erongo governor Cleopas Mutjavikua in which they expressed their support for former land reform deputy minister Bernadus Swartboois push for changes to the resettlement programme.
Close to a 100 Chinese business community in Rundu and their employees took the streets protesting against the illegal hunting of wildlife
A suspected thief by was assaulted by Goreangab residents. He survived the attack.
Keetmanshoop residents staged a protest against the passing of a land bill until after the completion of a second conference.
Residents of Mariental marched against skewed housing allocations.
Resident of Grootfontein and the Landless People's Movement held a demonstration in Grootfontein.
Approximately 120 residents of Schlip settlement in the Hardap Region took to the streets in protest of violence against women and children at the settlement.
A poacher was killed in an exchange of gunfire after a group of four men opened fire on police who were tracking them Bwabwata National Park.
People protest outside Katutura court against the granting of bail to a suspected murderer
In protest, Usakos residents petitioned Erongo governor Cleophas Mutjavikua to intervene to stop alleged corruption and mismanagement at the town.
A group of students from the Oshakati campus protested against the lack of accommodation on campus, charging that Oshakati is the only campus without a hostel.
More than 50 vendors at the Oshakati Open Market (omatala) disagree with the monthly rental fee and staged a peaceful march to demand a reduction.
Unemployed people staged a protest to demand cement jobs at Otjiwarongo.
An Oshakati man succumbed to the injuries he sustained after a mob beat him for allegedly robbing a woman at the Oneshila location in Oshakati.
Students gathered in protests at Uman
In Lwanyanda, Zambezi region, members of the community gathered in from of the Katima Mulilo police station to protest the recent land grabbing.
People protestded in Gibeon village in the Hardap region to highlight the socio-economic challenges they are facing.

A group of employees at the Motor Vehicle Accident (MVA) Fund held a peaceful demonstration and handed over a petition to management in which they expressed their dissatisfaction regarding working conditions.
Hundreds of disgruntled vendors demonstrated peacefully at the Helao Nafidi town at Oshikango in the Ohangwena region.
Swakopmund residents across the racial, social and economic spectrum protested over the murder of two people.

column7: TUN: Teachers Union of Namibia; Students (Namibia); Teachers (Namibia)
column17: More than 150 University of Namibia (Unam) Khomasdal campus student teachers, led by Teachers Union of Namibia (TUN), protest-marched in Windhoek to demand that the Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture releases the bulletin of teacher vacancies for 2018
About 100 placard-waving community members from Kehemu and Kaisosi settlement took to the streets to demonstrate on the slow response on the land issue by the Rundu Town Council (RTC).
Parents on Monday barred children and teachers from entering the school premises by locking the gates.

column7: MUN: Mineworkers Union of Namibia; Labour Group (Namibia)
column17: On 15 November 2017, about 600 workers affiliated to the Mineworkers Union of Namibia (MUN) participated in a peaceful demonstration and handed a petition to management in Swakopmund. [size=600].

Thousands of Zimbabweans residing in Namibia marched to that country's embassy in Windhoek in solidarity with demonstrations throughout the region in support of the removal of president Robert Mugabe.
The police at Ondangwa prevented a group of about 50 members of the Ondonga community from entering the authority offices premises at Ondangwa Town's Olunono suburb.
A group of some 40 vendors from the Frans AupaIndongo Open Market at Oshakati staged a peaceful demonstration for the second time this year demanding affordable municipal services.

Over 70 mine workers of the DYS demonstrated in front of the company's building in Katutura under the leadership of the Mineworkers Union of Namibia (MUN) demanding the management to relook at the decision to cut their salary and meet them half way.
Youth of Gibeon in the //Karas region staged a peaceful demonstration over what they claimed was the ""unfair"" employment of ""struggle kids"".
On 27 March, close to 100 black farmers took to the streets in Windhoek and marched to the Ministry of Finance to protest current farm expropriation plans.
On 19 April, hundreds of Katima Mulilo residents held a peaceful demonstration, rejecting the prepaid water meters which the town council has started to install here.
On 23 April, 100 employees of the Namibian Institute of Pathology held a demonstration in the capital to demand the implementation of a 10% salary increment.
On 9 May, Keetmanshoop student nurses took to the streets in a march to celebrate International Nurses Day.
On 13 May, anti-graft protests took place in Katima Mulilo as residents took to the streets to protest against alleged corruption and mismanagement by local authority councillors.
On 14 May, residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Kastima Mulilo to express their dissatisfaction with the council that has become very unpopular and is seen as not pro-poor.
On 26 May, 200 members of the Walvis Bay community staged a peaceful demonstration, calling for justice over the death of 20-year-old who allegedly drowned at Long Beach.

On 7 June, In Zambezi Region, NBC employees for both radio and television, under the leadership of the Namibia Public Worker's Union (NAPWU), marched from the public library to the broadcaster's regional office in Katima Mulilo, where they handed over their petition to the acting manager Simataa Buchane.
On 24 June, a mob in Wanaheda caught a man who was stealing a generator and beat him up before taking him to the nearest police station. The man eventually passed away in the 24th June.

On 3 July, employees staged a peaceful demonstration in Windhoek to show their disappointment in the NTB board and the company's negotiating committee for not meeting their salary and wages increment demand.
On 20 July, a group unemployed graduates 200 took to the streets of Windhoek , marching to the zoo park where they read and handed over their petition addressed to the prime minister.

On 1 August, more than 50 men and women marched from the Katutura Intermediate Hospital to the Windhoek Magistrate's Court in solidarity against gender-based violence, and to raise awareness about the scourge.

On 8 August, students from various tertiary institutions in northern Namibia joined their colleagues in Windhoek in protesting against the delays in the paying out of their study loans from Namibia Students Financial Assistance Fund (NASFAF). They walked for 2km from Yetu Shopping Complex in the Oshakati East to the offices of the Oshana Regional Council.
On 16 August, NBC employees held a peaceful demonstration outside a building in Otjiwarongo, demanding a salary increase of 6 per cent.
On 7 September, close to 500 people took part in an anti-Gender Based Violence march in Katutura.

On 20 September. Nearly 400 workers of the Otjikoto B2Gold Mine Namibia near Otavi in the Otjozondjupa Region staged a peaceful demonstration at the mine over unfair labour practices, victimisation and unprocedural disciplinary actions.
On 26 September, nearly 50 TransNamib train operators at Otjiwarongo staged a peaceful demonstration during their lunchtime demanding a salary increment.
On 1 October, demonstrators opposing the hosting of the second national land conference gathered in protest in Windhoek.

column7: NCCU: Namibia Cabin Crew Union; Labour Group (Namibia)
column17: On 4 October, employees represented by the Namibia Cabin Crew Union (NCCU) held a peaceful demonstration at its head office in Windhoek.

column7: MUN: Mineworkers Union of Namibia; Labour Group (Namibia)
column17: On 5 October, Mineworkers Union of Namibia (MUN) and the community of Warmbad staged a mass demonstration against the dismissal of 94 employees at the Tantalite Mine.

On 19 October, nearly 50 women street vendors operating in the Windhoek Central Business District (CBD) staged a peaceful demonstration at the Ministry of Gender Equality and Child Welfare to express their frustration of alleged mistreatment by the City Police.

column7: MUN: Mineworkers Union of Namibia; Labour Group (Namibia)
column17: On 19 October, the Mineworkers Union of Namibia (MUN) during a peaceful demonstration accused the Skorpion Zinc mine at Rosh Pinah of exploiting workers to maximise profits.
On 19 October, the Mothers' Union of the Anglican Church Diocese of Namibia held a peaceful march in Outapi in the Omusati Region to call for an end to gender-based violence (GBV).

On 5 November, police in Outapi (Uutapi) used pepper spray to disperse about 100 street vendors who went on an angry rampage, after the police allegedly confiscated and threw away the goods they were selling. Vendors threw stones at the police vehicles that were disposed to the scene to quell the riot.
On 8 November, protests tool place as about 100 Tses youth demonstrated against the employment of a liberation struggle kid at the Nowak Primary School, where they locked out teachers and pupils.
On 10 November, a group of community members from Swakopmund held a silent march against the increasing cases of Gender Based Violence (GBV) around the country.

On 12 November, about 100 Keetmanshoop residents demanded that Cabinet should reverse its decision that forces government institutions to employ children of the liberation struggle at the expense of locals.
On 16 November, in Arandis, residents demonstrated to express their lack of trust in their elected leaders.
On 21 November, 300 residents of Kombat staged a peaceful demonstration against their high monthly rental housing fees at the town.

On 23 November, a group of unemployed Keetmanshoop youth camped in protest in front of the Office of the Kharas Governor, they accused the incumbent, Lucia Basson of ignoring and neglecting their cry.
On 27 November, Swakopmund municipal workers held a demonstration to demanded a pay rise.
On 28 November, MEATCO workers protested in Windhoek against acting chief executive Jannie Breytenbach and executive for livestock procurement Heiner Bohme, whom they accused of poor management.
On Jan 18th, an Affirmative Repositioning (AR) activist sustained injuries following his arrest. He was hospitalized under police guard.
On Jan 18th, Zimbabwean nationals peacefully protested and handed over a petition to their Embassy, condemning violent acts during the fuel price protests in Zimbabwe.

On March 5th, construction workers handed over petitions to the Ministries of Works and Transport, Finance and to the Road Authority (RA) demanding that all capital construction projects be awarded to Namibian companies. [Size=200]

Around Mar 17th (exact date not reported) student from DHPS in Windhoek held a peaceful demonstration demanding a change on environmental policy to better face the effects of climate change. [size=no report]
On Apr 19th, protesters in Windhoek marched demanding the Government to legalise Marijuana. [Size=unknown]
On May 2nd, in Dordabis, farmers held a protest demanding absentee landlords in the area to allow their livestock graze on their farms. [Size=100]
13 June. A Namibian Defense Force (NDF) soldier killed a Zimbabwean national in Windhoek, Khomas for failing to stop at a road block.

On June 21st, Karasburg residents staged a protest against the appointment of more than 100 people from other regions as general workers for a TransNamib railway construction project. [Size=no report]
On Aug 10th, women marched for world peace, gender equality and social justice in Windoek. [Size=no report]
On Sept 5th, a member of Namibian Defence Force killed a man after the man refused to hand over his cellphone which he used to record a video of an Operation Kalahari Desert raid.

column7: NUNW: National Union of Namibian Workers; Labour Group (Namibia); TUCNA: Trade Union Congress of Namibia; Fishermen (Namibia)
column17: On 09 September 2019, in Walvis Bay workers in the fishing industry staged a mass protest against marine phosphate mining, demanding the government not to grant prospective mining companies an environmental clearance certificate. [size=1000]
On or around Sept 17th, employees of the Agriculture Business Development (AGRIBUSDEV) in Rundu staged a demonstration to demand salary increments and improved working conditions. [Size=no report]

On Sept 17th, 20 final-year diesel mechanic students at the Namibian Institute of Mining and Technology (Nimt)'s Keetmanshoop campus staged a protest accusing the institution's management of not taking their grievances seriously. They also demonstrated over what they called an ""incompetent training officer"", demanding the appointment of a new one. [Size=20]
On Sept 20th, as part of the wild-world FridayForFuture movement, students in Windhoek marched calling for action against climate change. [Size=no report]
On Sept 24th, in Windhoek, 30 workers at the Namibian Broadcasting Corporation's offices staged a demonstration to demand that the broadcaster reverses the austerity measures. [Size=30]

On Sept 25th, inhabitants of the Omaheke region held a demonstration against the alleged corrupt practices at the regional council, self-enrichment by officials, and lack of development for the community. [Size=50]
On Sept 28th, residents marched in Kuisebmond to protest over domestic violence. [Size=no report]

On Oct 3rd, the residents of Lwanyanda informal settlement at Katima Mulilo held a peaceful demonstration against the Katima Mulilo Town Council (KMTC)'s decision to have them relocated. [Size=hundreds]

On Oct 8th, residents of Okamatapati staged a peaceful demonstration to oppose a government decision to hire 13 children of the liberation struggle as cleaners, workhands and labourers at settlements in the Otjozondjupa region. [Size=50]
On Oct 20th 2019, contract cleaners gathered in Katutura to demand an improvement in their working conditions. [size=hundreds]
On Oct 22nd 2019, in Rundu, residents of the Tumweneni informal settlement, held a peaceful protest in front of the town council over the eviciton order they received. [size=no report]
On Oct 24th 2019, Tsumeb municipality employees struck and gathered at the municipality's technical department building to demand a 6 percent increase in their salaries. [size=130]

Around Oct 30th 2019 (exact date not reported) employees of the Windhoek Country Club and Resort held a peaceful protest, demanding the Labour Commissioner to recuse Conciliator Amupadhi from the resolution of a dispute between workers and the company, accusing her of inefficience and of being unprofessional. column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: AQIM killed the two male French hostages, who are discovered by government forces following a firefight to recover them
Nigers security forces fought a gun battle with gunmen holding two westerners hostage, but the kidnappers escaped, according to a security source and state radio on Saturday.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Military forces capture two suspected hostage takers soon after a clash.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 24 January, an Algerian army unit destroyed four off-road vehicles and killed four armed men thought to be militants belonging to the Al-Qaidah in the Lands of the Islamic Maghreb. The ambush took place near the town of Samaga inside Niger.

""This morning (Friday) we had planned a meeting followed by a peaceful march in support of the Libyan people, with the aim of condemning the Western attacks, but the municipality banned this,"" organizer Saboussi Jackou told a private radio station.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: ""The armed men who clashed with the Niger army on Sunday 50 miles north of Arlit were Islamist elements of AQIM,"" the security official told AFP on condition of anonymity. One soldier, one militant killed.
Police disperse protesters angry over electricity blackouts throughout the town. Several were wounded when police use teargas. 20 arrested.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An army patrol in Niger attacked a four-car convoy carrying suspected al-Qaida-linked militants, killing three of them and leading to the liberation of more than four dozen youths that had been forcibly recruited by the extremist group, the defense minister said.

Fourteen killed during a shootout with ""heavily armed"" attackers from Libya in northern Niger, where the Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) group operates. Authorities took 13 prisoners in the incident.

Clashes between security forces and protesters have killed at least two people after crowds gathered to protest against the arrest of an opposition figure and former minister under the regime of Mamadou Tandja. The police chief was later fired over the deaths.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: Five African aid workers who were abducted in Niger in mid-October have been freed alive, while a sixth has died after being shot by the Al-Qaeda-linked kidnappers.

Defection: About 400 men who deserted from Malis army after an offensive by Tuareg and Islamist rebels in the north have arrived in neighbouring Niger and are camped at Saguia a village at the south of the capital Niamey.
A vehicle carrying West African migrants toward Libya struck an anti-tank mine in Niger, killing seven people.
Clashes in southwestern Niger pitting farmers against herders over a long-disputed piece of land has left seven people dead.
Members of an unidentified armed group clashed with Nigerian security forces after attempting to force a military checkpoint.

In recent weeks, unknown people have thrown rocks into a church compound in Zinder and destroyed its security lights. Others have hurled insults from outside the gate. In one incident, a pastors wife was pelted with stones as she left the church.
Several Christian leaders are being held in protective custody in Niger after demonstrators angry at an anti-Islam film ransacked a major Catholic church.
Five aid workers and a driver were kidnapped over the weekend by gunmen who initially planned to abduct an Italian anthropologist.
The Oil minister was attacked during a protest
Movement of forces: Military forces of France entered Niger to protect the Francais Areva uranium mines.

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Movement of forces: 40 members of the Military Forces of the United States enter Niger as part of the force being sent to Mali. This brings to 100 the number of US troops in Niger.
Some 2,000 students held a protest in Nigers capital Niamey on Friday against French nuclear group Areva demand their country get a bigger slice of its uranium mining revenues.

There were three days of rioting and clashes at Diffa, in the far southern part of Niger yesterday [26 April]. The inhabitants took to the streets to demand jobs on the crude oil sites in the region. But clashes broke out between them and the security agents. Several persons have been injured following clashes.

There were three days of rioting and clashes at Diffa, in the far southern part of Niger yesterday [26 April]. The inhabitants took to the streets to demand jobs on the crude oil sites in the region. But clashes broke out between them and the security agents. Several persons have been injured following clashes.

There were three days of rioting and clashes at Diffa, in the far southern part of Niger yesterday [26 April]. The inhabitants took to the streets to demand jobs on the crude oil sites in the region. But clashes broke out between them and the security agents. Several persons have been injured following clashes.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: MUJAO targerted a mining companies factory in Arlit, northern Agadez with a bomb. 1 killed & between 14 and 50 wounded.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: MUJAO targerted a military camp in Agadez with a bomb. An exchange of fire ensued. This is the first MUJAO attack in Niger.18 Niger soldiers killed &4 MUJAO.

column8: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: French troops assaulted MUJAO militants in Agadez following yesterdays suicide attacks. 2 killed.
Non-violent activity: French & Niger troops raid an army base to free hostages taken during the twin suicide attacks of 23 May.
An armed group identifying themselves as ""Signatories in Blood"" attacked a a paramilitary barracks in the capital Niamey. They were repelled with no caualties.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram attacked Niamey prison and attacked Salafis prisoners. Niger troops surrounded the prison and a clash ensued. 3 died, 3 prison guards injured.
Niger military attacked a suspected militant vehicle in Niamey, killing 4.
A group of angry citizens clashed with Military in Niamey. Police intervened and one citizen was killed.
Riots led to clashes with security forces. A checkpoint was burned. 37 people wounded.
During protests, 2 women were abducted by an unknown armed group. One person was held hostage for 2 days.
Citizens protested security measures and release of a french foreign national from jail
2 day clashes with drug traffickers
2 day clashes with drug traffickers
Thousands of people protested against pollution by French nuclear firm Areva, which has been mining uranium in Arlit.

column7: USN: Union of Nigerien Schools; Students (Niger)
column17: Hundreds of high school students took to the streets on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in Niamey calling for better study conditions in a march organised by the USN. Some protestors burned tyres and threw stones at police who responded with tear gas.

column7: USN: Union of Nigerien Schools; Students (Niger)
column17: Hundreds of high school students took to the streets on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in Niamey calling for better study conditions in a march organised by the USN. Some protestors burned tyres and threw stones at police who responded with tear gas.

column7: USN: Union of Nigerien Schools; Students (Niger)
column17: Hundreds of high school students took to the streets on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in Niamey calling for better study conditions in a march organised by the USN. Some protestors burned tyres and threw stones at police who responded with tear gas.

Over one thousand people marched in Niamey to denounce the ""unbalanced partnership"" between Niger and the French Areva group, which has operated in uranium for forty years in the north of the country. Operations have since been suspended.

column7: ARDR: Alliance for the Republic, Democracy and Reconciliation in Niger
column17: Tens of thousands of people have protested in Niamey against President Mahamadou Issoufou and the governments failure to improve living conditions. They protested against corruption, dictatorship and the censoring of media for opposition parties.
Hundreds of students rioted through the streets of Zinder, ransacking police vehicles. 20 held for questioning by police.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Recruitment: Boko Haram has begun recruiting in southern Niger, around Diffa province, via an insurgency group in the country which claims to be paid by Boko Haram for their services

column8: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: A Niger military contingent arrested 14 heavily armed Boko Haram gunmen after a running battle in the Diffa region; 2 of the gunmen were wounded; they were ambushed by security forces after attacking a shopkeeper; eight motorcycles and cell phones were seized

Unidentified armed assailants attacked the home of one of the members of the ruling Nigerien Party for Democracy and Socialism; the son of the Niger speaker and two relatives were arrested in connection with the attack

Two days of student rioting have left 10 people injured, as well as 26 cars and 6 motorbikes badly damaged, while students also ransacked the premises of Nigers Grant Allocation Agency; student attacked police with stones and hunks of wood, while police used tear gas to disperse the protesters; the students were protesting delays to grant payments; at least 72 have been arrested

Two days of student rioting have left 10 people injured, as well as 26 cars and 6 motorbikes badly damaged, while students also ransacked the premises of Nigers Grant Allocation Agency; student attacked police with stones and hunks of wood, while police used tear gas to disperse the protesters; the students were protesting delays to grant payments; at least 72 have been arrested
Three people were injured, one severely, in a molotov cocktail attack on the ruling Nigerien Party for Democracy and Socialism HQ

column7: MODEM: Nigerian Democratic Movement for an African Federation; CDS-Rahama: Democratic and Social Convention-Rahama
column17: Thousands of Nigerians attended a peaceful march organized by the Nigerian opposition to demand ""respect for civil liberties"" and the release of political prisoners, in response to the jailing of many opposition activists last month

French special forces carried out a raid on a GMA convoy, striking 1 vehicle from the air and killing 3 occupants, then landing special forces and capturing multiple militants, including Abu Asum al-Muhajir, the spokesperson for GMA.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The French military used jets to destroyed part of an AQIM convoy transporting weapons from Libya to Mali in cooperation with Nigerien authorities. They then landed special forces who killed/captured 15 AQIM militants. Large amounts of weapons were captured, and some were killed, wounded or captured, but no specific numbers were reported.

The French military has announced it will be establishing a forward base in Madama alongside the government of Niger to intensify its operations against militants in northern Mali and cut off their supply routes. About 50 French soldiers will be deployed, and it should be operations ""within the coming weeks"".

Several unidentified gunmen (allegedly militants who shouted ""God is Greatest"" during their attacks) on motorcycles attacked the multiple locations in the locality of Ouallam. Unidentified gunmen attacked a prison in Ouallam, which held both many Tuareg separatists and MUJAO prisoners, and released 58 people.

Several unidentified gunmen (allegedly militants who shouted ""God is Greatest"" during their attacks) on motorcycles attacked the multiple locations in the locality of Ouallam.Unidentified gunmen attacked a patrol of the security services in the locality of Zaramou Darey. 2 national guard members and 2 security forces members were killed.

Several unidentified gunmen (allegedly militants who shouted ""God is Greatest"" during their attacks) on motorcycles attacked the multiple locations in the locality of Ouallam. Unidentified gunmen attacked a Malian refugee camp in the locality of Mangaize, and burned the camps police station, killing at least 5 policemen, 1 civilian, and wounding 4 refugees. 3 attackers were also killed, and 4 others captured.
10 people were killed and 13 injured in a confrontation between farmers and herders in the area of Birnin Nkoni.

Movement of forces: Between 300 and 2200 Nigerian soldiers retreated into Niger and took refuge in the town of Bosso after an attack against Boko Haram forces in Malamfatari. They were later transferred to the regional capital of Diffa and transported back to Nigeria.
Officers of the Mining Corporation AIR (SOMAIR) have gone on strike to protest against an alleged wave of unfair dismissals. The workers engaged in a sit-in.

Municipal police in Niamey have begun a 48-hour strike without minimum service to demand better working and living conditions. The strike was violently repressed by security forces with municipal officials and dozens of other injured.

column6: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
column17: ""Armed men [allegedly militants] from northern Mali, aboard motorcycles, led an attack on Banibangou... killing a Nigerian policeman"" and injuring two more during a two hour gunfight. The attack was claimed by MUJAO, and at least 1 of their fighters was killed and an unspecified number injured (they took the bodies with them).

Movement of forces: The Niger military has engaged in ""the largest military operation ever mounted in Niger"" called Ingar, which has seen extensive deployment of the military to the east around Diffa to protect against Boko Haram.
Demonstrators angry about cartoons of the Prophet Mohammad published by Charlie Hebdo rioted in Maradi.

One policeman and three others have been killed in violent protests against French magazine Charlie Hebdo in Nigers second city of Zinder. It is unclear whether the other three deaths were among demonstrators or civilians attacked by demonstrators.

Rioters in Niger angry about the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammad by Charlie Hebdo attacked Christians and Christian-owned buildings, including homes and businesses. They also looted and burned at least 3 Catholic churches. Christian have been put under military protection in the city, subsequent deaths reported on following day
At least five people were killed on Saturday during a second day of unrest in Niger; 4 of the victims were civilians who died when churches or other buildings were set alight.

column7: ARDR: Alliance for the Republic, Democracy and Reconciliation in Niger
column17: About 300 members of the opposition held a protest in the wake of recent violence against demonstrators, despite a government ban. Police fired tear gas and arrested up to 90 members of the opposition. Those arrested were released Friday the 24th.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram launched simultaneous attacks on Bosso and near Diffa. Troops from Niger and Chad fought back and killed 109 militants in total. Four soldiers also died in the clashes.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram launched simultaneous attacks on Bosso and near Diffa. Troops from Niger fought back and killed 109 militants in total. Four soldiers also died in the clashes.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram staged an overnight assault on the town of Diffa. The Niger military fought back and the militants fled. Death toll is unknown.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram attacked Diffa and conducted a concurrent suicide bombing in the market left at least six dead and several injured.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Sahara Reporters; AFP; Deutsche Welle; AP; Xinhua
column17: Boko Haram continued its assault on Diffa and Bosso, including on a prison in Diffa, and Niger troops successfully repelled them. At least one national guard member was killed at the prison and 3 other soldiers in total, plus a total of 300 Boko Haram fighters from Sunday - Tuesday.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram continued its assault on Diffa and Bosso, and at least one national guard member and 3 other soldiers died in total, plus 300 Boko Haram fighters from Sunday - Tuesday.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram launched another attack on Diffa, but the Nigerien military was able to repel them. A total of 300 Boko Haram were killed from Sunday - Tuesday.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: In ongoing clashes between Boko Haram and the Nigerien military, a total of 300 Boko Haram fighters were killed between Sunday- Tuesday.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: A female suicide bomber was shot dead before detonating explosives in Diffa.
An airstrike by an unidentified plane killed one person.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Three Boko Haram members attacked a military post with knives. A police man was injured.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: A would-be suicide bomber was shot dead after trying to detonate next to a military post. A military explosive expert was seriously injured while defusing the device.
Protesters marched against Boko Haram and in favor of the Nigerian military in light of recent attacks near the border with Nigeria.
Protesters marched against Boko Haram and in favor of the Nigerian military in light of recent attacks near the border with Nigeria.
Protesters marched against Boko Haram and in favor of the Nigerian military in light of recent attacks near the border with Nigeria.

36 people were killed and 27 injured when an unidentified plane bombed civilians attending a funeral ceremony on the border with Nigeria. It is unclear who is responsible, but local leaders point to Nigerias army or Boko Haram.
Up to 35,000, led by the President and Prime Minister, marched against Boko Haram and in support of the Nigerien military following a series of attacks along the Nigerian border.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Seven soldiers, 15 Boko Haram fighters and one civilian were killed in a battle on an island on the Nigerien side of Lake Chad. At least 4 soldiers were seriously injured and 5 unaccounted for.
2 Niger soldiers were killed and 4 others wounded when their vehicle hit a mine.
Security Measures: The government of Niger extended the state of emergency in the Diffa region, which borders Nigeria and has recently come under attack by Boko Haram.
2 people were killed when their horse-drawn cart hit a mine in Zaourararm, in the Diffa area.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram attacked three islands on the Nigerien side of Lake Chad, and at least 19 civilians died of bullet wounds, fire, and drowning.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram attacked the islands of Kouiklewa, Tombon Bouka, and another island near Tombon Bouka on the Nigerien side of Lake Chad, and at least 19 civilians died of bullet wounds, fire, and drowning.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram attacked three islands on the Nigerien side of Lake Chad, and at least 19 civilians died of bullet wounds, fire, and drowning.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 2 March 2015, Boko Haram destroyed a mobile telephone operators installations.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram burned down a village near Bosso, killing two fishermen.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Two Nigerien troops were killed by a landmine and the two Boko Haram fighters who activated the device were killed in response.
Troops from Niger and Chad killed 40-47 Boko Haram fighters when they repelled an attack in Bosso.

Boko Haram attacked a Nigerien army position on the island Karamga on Lake Chad, resulting in the deaths at a reported 46 soldiers, 28 civilians and 156 militants. 32 troops are missing. Nigers military maintains control of the island and has asked residents to evacuate.
Boko Haram killed at least five civilians and burned houses and vehicles in an attack on Koukoudou village. They also looted homes and shops before withdrawing back into Nigeria.

3 members of an armed group were killed in clashes with the joint French Operation Barkhane and Niger soldiers on the the Niger-Libya border, just south of the Salvador Pass. 3 others were taken prisoner and the authorities seized drugs, firearms, and communications equipment.
Thousands protested on the streets of Niamey against poor government management, including electrical outages.
Boko Haram attacked a village in the Bosso region, clashing with defense forces.
During a Boko Haram attack on a village in the Bosso region, the militants killed at least one and kidnapping two boys.
Boko Haram attacked Lamana and a neighbouring village with guns, setting homes on fire and killing at least 38 people, including 10 children.

In response to Boko Harams attack on Gueskerou on June 17, the Nigerien military launched ground and air operations from June 18 - 23. The offensive left 15 militants dead, 20 arrested, and a number of vehicles destroyed, with no injuries reported on the part of the army.

In response to Boko Harams attack on Gueskerou on June 17, the Nigerien military launched ground and air operations from June 18 - 23. The offensive left 15 militants dead, 20 arrested, and a number of vehicles destroyed, with no injuries reported on the part of the army.

Boko Haram killed five people and injured four others in an attack on a town near Bosso. The militants used guns and set fire to victims, homes, and vehicles as well as the central market.

In response to Boko Harams attack on Gueskerou on June 17, the Nigerien military launched ground and air operations from June 18 - 23. The offensive left 15 militants dead, 20 arrested, and a number of vehicles destroyed, with no injuries reported on the part of the army.
Boko Haram slit the throats of five civilians during a targeted attack against workers from the Diffa area who were working near Bosso.

3 Boko Haram fighters and 1 officer of the Nigerien national guard were killed in an attack on the civilian prison in Diffa. The officer was killed when one of the attackers detonated an explosive belt, while another guard was injured.
The Nigerien army claims to have killed at least 30 Boko Haram members between July.15-17. In one encounter, 10 militants were killed while an 2 people were captured, including an important emir.
As many as 10 residents of Gamgara, in the Bosso area, were killed in an attack by Boko Haram, while several others were seriously injured.
The Nigerien army claims to have killed at least 30 Boko Haram members between July.15-17. In one encounter, 10 militants were killed while an 2 people were captured, including an important emir.

Clashes between Fulani and Nupe youth in Kakakpangi village in Katchan Katchan area. 2 killed. Police deployed to the area.
Boko Haram cross from Nigeria into Komadougou Yobe and kill 15 civilians.
On their way to protect the village of Baroua, troops were ambushed by Boko Haram who killed 2 and wounded 7.
At least one suicide bombing took place, perhaps two, when police confronted suspected members of Boko Haram, who then detonated explosives. A policeman, 4 militants, and at least 5 civilians died.
Detonation: Three Boko Haram militants died when a bomb they were transporting exploded.

Security Measures: The council of ministers placed the region of Diffa under a state of emergency for two weeks. This allows authorities to impose curfews and limit movement as part of the fight against Boko Haram.
Insurgents conducted a raid and opened fire in the city, killing two civilians as they fled.

Violent clashes between police and students protesting for better study conditions left at least seven injured and led to 79 arrests. Demonstrators threw stones and set fires, while police used tear gas.
A suicide attacker killed himself and two soldiers on the outskirts of Diffa. The military killed three other would-be bombers at the scene.
Boko Haram attacked the Ala village just across the border from Nigeria in the Diffa region, killing 13 and injuring 3 while burning buildings.
Thousands protested in favor of ""credible elections""
A military convoy drove over a mine and then exchanged fire with Boko Haram. One soldier died.
The Niger army launched airstrikes against Boko Haram near the village of Dagaya. Casualty figures unknown, while 20 Boko Haram militants were arrested.

Opposition supporters and police clashed around the airport as opposition presidential candidate Hama Amadou arrived by plane and was immdiately arrested. Several rioters were also arrested and a child was reportedly killed by a motorcycle.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Gogone, killing 18 including the local imam, and burning 70 houses; villagers fought back with bows and arrows. 11 were injured and a child disappeared.
Boko Haram killed four, injured two, and burned about 50 homes in a cross-border raid.

At least 2 soldiers and 3 civilians were killed and others injured when Boko Haram attacked the village of Abadam.
Attack or clash reported involving Boko Haram; casualties unknown.
At least six soldiers were killed and five wounded when their vehicle hit an explosive device likely planted by Boko Haram.

Thousands of MODEN party supporters were dispersed by police using tear gas just before the presidents motorcade passed by. Clashes reported between MODEN supporters and police.

Thousands of students marched in memory of three youth who were killed by police in 1990.
Four suicide bombers believed to be with Boko Haram attacked a military convoy, killing themselves and one officer and injuring two others. A fifth attacker was shot before detonating.

4 Boko Haram fighters were killed and 3 captured during a fight with Nigerien security forces. This followed an ambush of Nigerien security forces the day before in the same area.
Double suicide bombing by Boko Haram killed at least 3 civilians and injured several, likely near Ngaroua village.
Mine explosion reported involving Boko Haram on the road between Ngaroua and Garin Dogo; casualties unknown.

At least 9 civilians killed and 13 injured in Boko Haram attack.
Hundreds of Boko Haram fighters attacked a military post, killing 24 Nigerien and 2 Nigerian soldiers and wounding 112. 55 Boko Haram killed.
Protesters marched in solidarity with the southeast of the country after recent Boko Haram attacks.
Attack or clash reported involving Boko Haram; casualties unknown.
Movement of forces: The first of an expected 2,000 Chadian troops began arriving in Niger to assist the fight against Boko Haram, as Nigerien special forces also moved into the area.
Following government and NGO representatives visit to a refugee camp, Boko Haram attacked paramilitary police stationed nearby, killing 7 and injuring 3.
Boko Haram attacked civilians during evening prayers, killing an imam and stealing food.
Thousands of protesters marched in eight regions of Niger in supporting the army fighting Boko Haram in Chad lake.

On Sept.30, a spokesman of Nigers defense ministry claimed that 123 Boko Haram militants and 14 Nigerien soldiers have been killed in joint operations with Chadian forces in the Diffa area since the beginning of July (7 soldier and 38 Boko Haram fatalities coded in other events; new fatalities divided between July, August and September in 3 events). 29 soldiers were also wounded and 2 Boko Haram members captured.

column17: At least 5 killed in attack attributed to Boko Haram.
Dozens of protesters were arrested and many injuries were reported after demonstrations over power shortages turned violent in Arlit.

column17: 5 civilians were killed and 2 wounded in a Boko Haram attack on Toumour (allegedly the first in 3 months). The attackers rode into town on camels and burned buildings before treating towards Nigeria. They were opposed by locals who were armed with bows and arrows.

column6: MJRN: Movement for Justice and the Rehabilitation of Niger
column17: Formation of armed group: A new armed group called the Movement for Justice and the Rehabilitation of Niger has threatened to launch attacks in the uranium-rich west African country of Niger to protest against the marginalisation of the minority Toubou population.
2 people were killed and 10 others injured by the Koglweogo vigilante group from Burkina Faso who claimed to have tracked down suspected bandits to an area across the border with Niger.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 2 Nigerien soldiers were killed and 2 others injured when their vehicle hit an IED planted by suspected Boko Haram fighters near Baroua.
2 Malian refugees and a policeman were killed and 4 wounded in an attack on the Tabarey Barey refugee camp in the Ayorou district by unidentified assailants.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: After a Boko Haram attack killed 5 soldiers, the Nigerien military responded with operations in the Gueskerou and Toumour areas that killed 30 and captured 2 Boko Haram fighters and recovered a large quantity of arms and ammunition.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: After a Boko Haram attack killed 5 soldiers, the Nigerien military responded with operations in the Gueskerou and Toumour areas that killed 30 and captured 2 Boko Haram fighters and recovered a large quantity of arms and ammunition.

column17: 5 Nigerien soldiers were killed and 6 others wounded in an ambush by Boko Haram fighters at Bosso in the Diffa area.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 38 Boko Haram fighters were killed in joint Nigerien/Chadian military operations around Gueskerou and Toumour between Sept.12-14 (30 fatalities coded in a previous event). 2 soldiers were lightly wounded and substantial quantities of weapons and ammunitions seized.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Nigerien and Chadian armed forces conducted airstrikes against Boko Haram positions ahead of a planned offensive.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 38 Boko Haram fighters were killed in joint Nigerien/Chadian military operations around Gueskerou and Toumour between Sept.12-14 (30 fatalities coded in a previous event). 2 soldiers were lightly wounded and substantial quantities of weapons and ammunitions seized.

column17: On 30 Sept 2016, a spokesman of Nigers defense ministry claimed that 123 Boko Haram militants and 14 Nigerien soldiers have been killed in joint operations with Chadian forces in the Diffa area since the beginning of July (7 soldier and 38 Boko Haram fatalities coded in other events; new fatalities divided between July, August and September in 3 events). 29 soldiers were also wounded and 2 Boko Haram members captured.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 21 September, 3 Boko Haram members were captured by villagers when they attempted to enter their area near Diffa during the night. They were later transferred to the local gendarmerie post.

Striking students from Niamey University erected barricades in front of their campus and blocked traffic to demand attention to their grievances. Police were deployed but did not engage the protesters.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The Nigerien government confirmed that 22 Nigerien soldiers were killed in an attack by suspected AQIM fighters on a Malian refugee camp in the Tazalit area of Tassara commune. At least one refugee was also injured and an ambulance burned. The attackers arrived in a column made up of at least 13 vehicles and a motorcycle and fled after the attack.
Several teachers unions in Niger began a 3-day strike. Teachers also staged a march through the streets of Niamey.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 50 Boko Haram members raided the Diffa area and robbed shops, pharmacies, health centres and other buildings. No casualties were reported however.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An American aid worker with the NGO Youth with a Mission was kidnapped and two people, a bodyguard and a Nigerien national guardsman, were killed in an attack by suspected AQIM fighters in Abalak. Government sources claimed the kidnappers headed for the Malian border.

Malian-based militants attacked Koutoulake prison close to Niamey which houses militants from al-Qaeda, Boko Haram and other militant groups active in the area. One attacker was killed during the attack and 2 guards injured. IS later claimed responsibility for the attack.

At least 18 people were killed and 43 others wounded in clashes between farmers and herders near Bangui, a town in the region of Tahoua (west). 38 suspected arrested. Some days after, two persons succumbed to their injuries raising the deaths at 20.
At the University of Zinder, clashes took place between students and police over the payment of scholarships and especially a steady supply of food in the university restaurant.

Five soldiers were killed, three injured and four others missing following an attack on Tuesday in the town of Banibangou. Two of the attackers were also killed in the raid, and that 26 others were arrested with weapons and ammunition. The Islamic State group is said to be behind this attack.

Clashes between students and security forces over the strike of teachers which lasts for several months and the payment of their scholarship. Students burned tires and erected barricades while police responded with tear gas. Dozens of arrests and wounded among the protesters.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 3 civilians were killed in a raid by Boko Haram on Wor village. The attackers also burned some huts before retreating.
At least 2 Nigerien gendarmes were killed in an ambush of their convoy in Bankilare. Ansar Dine and AQIM have both been active in the area.
At least 10,000 people, including striking civil servants and traders, protested against the allegedly mismanagement of President Issoufous government and rising costs of living.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Agreement: 30 Boko Haram fighters surrendered to the authorities in Nigers Diffa region.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: At least 3 soldiers and 5 Boko Haram militants were killed in an attack on army positions in the Marouwa area of Diffa region. 7 more soldiers were wounded in the attack. Other reports said as many as 15 Boko Haram militants were killed and one captured.

column7: PNDS: Nigerien Party for Democracy and Socialism
column17: As many as 20,000 people took part in a march in Niamey in support of the current government and President Mahamadou Issoufou. The event was organized by the ruling MNR coalition and was led by the president of the PNDS (the main ruling party).

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Many Boko Haram fighters were killed () by Nigerien air strikes as they attempted to retreat through the marshes near Lake Chad after they attacked a military base at Geskerou in the Diffa region.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 2 Nigerien soldiers were killed and 7 others wounded in an attack by a large number of Boko Haram fighters on a military base in Geskerou in the Diffa region. 3 army vehicles were also torched.

Non-violent activity: The Nigerien, Malian and Burkinabe governments have created a Multinational Security Force (MSF) under the auspices of the Integrated Development Authority of the Liptako-Gourma Region (LGA) to more effectively fight against militancy along their shared borders.
Thousands of people protested in Niamey against the government for alleged ""mismanagement"", high costs of living and allowing the presence of western military bases in their country.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 3 soldiers were killed in the Diffa area in an attack by suspected Boko Haram fighters.

column16: Niger Inter; Sahara Media; Xinhua; Le Figaro; AFP; Nord Sud Journal
column17: At least 16 soldiers were killed, including one officer, as many as 19 wounded, seven vehicles stolen, and four more burned by suspected Islamist fighters in an attack near Tilwa in the Ouallam area, near Mangaize. Other reports said at least 15 soldiers had been killed. An IS linked group led by Abou El Walid El Sahraou is believed to have carried out the attack.
At least 6 soldiers were killed in an ambush of their convoy as they were traveling on the road to Agadez. No group claimed responsibility.

A soldier was killed and 7 others injured, including 3 soldiers and 4 police, in a confrontation between soldiers and police in Dosso. The altercation started after police stopped a military vehicle for their driving.

Thousands of people marched in Niamey to protest against the government. They called for improved living conditions and the release of political prisoners. The march was called by an alliance of 11 opposition groups.

column8: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
column17: 5 gendarmes were killed in an attack by AQM militants in the Tillaberi region.
Nigerien security forces were attacked by suspected Islamist militants in the Dolbel area.
7 people were killed and 4 gendarmes wounded in an attack by suspected Islamist militants on Wanzarbe in the Bankilare area.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: A Nigerien soldier and 3 suspected Boko Haram militants were killed, while 11 others were injured, in an ambush by the militants against a Niger/Chad joint military patrol in the Bosso area.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Military forces in Niger claim they have killed 57 Boko Haram fighters while 15 soldiers and 2 civilians were lightly wounded in Gueskerou in the Diffa region. The Boko Haram fighters had attacked an army position in the area resulting in the clash.

Violent protests took place at the University of Niamey campus including clashes between students and police which led to at least one student killed and over 100 injured (88 protesters, 21 police). As many as 313 people were arrested out of the more than 20,000 students reported to have participated in the protests. The students reportedly blocked traffic and built barricades, and threw stones while the police used tear gas. The protesters were demanding better living/studying conditions.
Sporadic clashes have been reported between police and students in Niamey following violent protests on Apr.10.
Persistent mass protests have been reported throughout the week by the students in Niamey.

Clashes were reported between unidentified drug traffickers and a military patrol in the Ighayen area near Agadez. One of the drug traffickers was killed and a vehicle was destroyed. Militant groups across the Sahel often use drugs to fund their activities.

column16: Niamey et le deux jours; Menastream
column17: Unknown armed men opened fire on the military post. Two gendarmes dead and one civilian wounded. Ammunitions, weapons and two motos were stolen.
Protesters went down the street to complain about the bad governance and the lack of electric power. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd.
The gendarmerie camp in Ayorou attacked by unknown gunmen around 17h: 5 injured and 5 vehicles seized reported
Two Nigerian policemen, 1 civilian killed, 3 wounded amidst attack last night at 21h on police station in Petelkole on the border with Burkina Faso

The gendarmerie in Abala was attacked by unknown gunmen on vehicles seized during the Ayorou attack. Reports indicate 8 dead in the ranks of gendarmes and National Guards, in addition to several wounded and 2 vehicles seized. The aggressors were pursued and blocked by the army not far from the Malian border.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: A suicide attack by two women suspected to belong to BH killed three Nigerian refugees in the UN refugee camp for Nigerians of Kabalewa. 11 were wounded. The camp will be transferred to Sayam on Monday.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram jihadists have kidnapped 39 women and cut the throats of nine other people at Nglea village in southeastern Niger.

column6: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
column17: An army patrol was attacked this morning in Midal, Tahoua Region, near the Malian border. Barkhane aircrafts intervened. Provisional toll: 5 dead in the ranks of Niger security forces, vehicles & materiel seized, 1 vehicle recovered by Barkhane and Niger forces.

An air strike by Niger's army has killed 14 displaced people (two Nigeriens and 12 Nigerians) who were mistaken for jihadists in the restive southeast where Boko Haram Islamists have staged regular attacks, regional officials said Thursday.The victims were farmers who had fled the area around the village of Abadam on the Nigerian border due to the raging insurgency. They were killed in an air strike Wednesday as they returned to check on their crops, officials said.
Suspected insurgents (not named) abducted a Nigerian refugee in July. She was later released for ransom in Elhadji Mainari in Diffa.
Suspected insurgents (not names) killed five people and burnt down houses in Dagaya, Diffa region, in July.
Suspected insurgents (not named) killed a herder in Nuigmi in Diffa and robbed 200 livestock of his herd in July.
Suspected insurgents (not named) reportedly tortured and robbed people at Ngarwa village in Diffa on the 21st of July.

Authorities in Niger say at least a dozen paramilitary police have been killed in an attack. Reports said the attackers were heavily armed with guns and rocket launchers. They arrived in five vehicles to launch their ambush on a gendarmes base. The attackers left when Nigerien military reinforcements showed up. Updated toll: 13 dead, 5 wounded (Official Statement).
Fighting between Nigerien forces and the attackers is now reported in the area of In-Ates, on the border with Mali.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
